results.title: [Phillip Annett Home Movie]
results.brief_description:
This home movie was originally created on 16mm film by Phillip Annett. It was donated to ACMI by Daryl Annett.

This film is a snap shot of suburban life in Melbourne. There are wonderful examples of fashion, inner-Melbourne street scenes, architecture and cars of the time. We see a children’s birthday party and backyard games under the Hills Hoist as well as neighbours chatting over the fence to passers-by in the street. Men in Australian Army and Air Force uniforms pose and smile for the camera, and there are scenes of a road trip to regional Victoria. We see a fire truck display, horse and harness riding as well as woodchopping displays at the Royal Melbourne Show. There are candid images of a horse event competitor in the stables area of the Royal Melbourne Show, as well as St Kilda Road buses and trams as they travel down the road. Black and white images of a horse and cart and a man in a bowler hat performing tricks is a fantastic moment in time.

Selected highlights list (timecodes from Access Overscan)

00:00:03:00 Close-up of men’s faces as they walk past the camera, waving their hats and gesturing. Great snapshot of the period and fashion.
00:00:07:00 Men walking towards camera showing great examples of 1940s fashion, streetscape and vintage cars
00:00:33:00 People in the street with Mynor Fruit Cup and The Sun advertising in the background
00:00:45:00 Two men in the street with Mynor Fruit Cup advertising in the background
00:00:46:00 Man in the street with vintage Myer delivery truck in background
00:00:47:00 Men with baby in vintage pram showing excellent examples of men’s fashion
00:00:56:00 Two men in RAAF Uniforms walk towards and past the camera
00:01:08:00 Man walks towards camera and waves with vintage cars beside him in the street
00:01:14:00 Two school boys holding hands walk down the street towards the camera
00:01:19:00 Young man riding towards camera on his bicycle, he waves. Good example of streetscape.
00:01:21:00 Man in the street smoking a pipe with vintage cars in the background
00:01:24:00 Small boy points and shoots a toy gun showing good example of children’s fashion
00:01:25:00 Two children run down the footpath. Good children’s fashion and street view.
00:01:28:00 Boy and girl stand on footpath and blow kisses
00:01:32:00 Sequence of images showing various individuals standing outside their houses. Good example of houses and street.
00:01:34:00 Old man wearing trousers and braces walking down the footpath
00:01:43:00 Exterior images of period houses
00:01:55:00 View of Government House from the interior of a car as they drive under a bridge
00:02:00:00 Lindberg and Foster signage
00:02:04:00 Sequence of images of women walking, towards and past the camera waving. Good fashion reference.
00:02:11:00 Woman with pram and baby walking down the street
00:02:13:00 Women walking down the street showing great fashion examples
00:02:49:00 Show pony/horse in backyard with show ribbons adorning its back. Impressed onlookers observe the prize winner of the 1949 Coast National Exhibition.
00:03:33:00 A man and a woman walk down a country road, a vintage car drives past in the background
00:03:43:00 Diggers Rest Post Office and General Store
00:03:45:00 People standing in rural setting country Victoria
00:04:36:00 Royal Melbourne Show fire truck display in main arena including Northwood Park fire truck with woodchopping in background
00:05:12:00 Royal Melbourne Show horse riding and woodchopping display
00:05:28:00 Harness racing display at Royal Melbourne Show
00:05:37:00 Horse riding and horse flag and barrel event Royal Melbourne Show
00:05:49:00 Girl on dapple grey horse riding in front of stables at the Royal Melbourne Show
00:05:59:00 Inner Melbourne street scenes, possibly Parkville
00:06:26:00 McInerney’s Hotel Max, Victoria Bitter, Orlando Wines signage on exterior brick wall. Great vintage car and period houses in front of sign.
00:06:29:00 Children in birthday party fashion attire
00:07:04:00 Children in party fashion outfits in suburban backyard with Hills Hoist, mums join in the fun
00:07:28:00 Men and women display great hair fashion of the day as they walk towards camera
00:07:37:00 Children at the birthday party stand under the Hills Hoist and watch a man riding a child’s three-wheel bike
00:07:41:00 Older man leads the birthday party children under the Hills Hoist. Good fashion reference for children.
00:07:55:00 Black and white horse and cart in front of Mynor Fruit Cup advertising. Man in bowler hat and braces runs back and forth and kicks his legs in the air. Great old footage from the time.
00:08:05:00 Women standing in front of sign for the Narbethong Blacks Spur Hotel
00:08:19:00 Man in uniform walks along the street outside pub/hotel
00:08:23:00 Two men talking in front of pub smiling and laughing. Good street and fashion scene in front of a pub/hotel.
00:08:30:00 Two women walk along the street pushing a woman in a wheel chair. They pass a Reckitts Blue advertising sign on a brick wall.
00:08:39:00 North Road City St Kilda Road bus
00:08:45:00 Melbourne number 7 945 tram to the city with signage “Ride in Comfort travel between 9.30 and 4.00”
00:09:01:00 Women exiting the pub/hotel onto the street. Good fashion reference.

results.title: Phantom Ride
results.credit_line:
Daniel Crooks

Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection.

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore
results.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape that shifts our perceptions of space and time.

constellations_primary.name: Taking it slow
constellations_primary.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

results.description:
Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

“Phantom Ride comes out of my long-held fascination with the convergence of trains, the birth of cinema and modern ideas and representations of time.

I’ve presented it as a two-sided video; the forward-facing journey on one side and the rear looking journey on the reverse. The screen becomes a meniscus of the present, separating the past and the future.” - Daniel Crooks
description_for_label:
Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

“Phantom Ride comes out of my long-held fascination with the convergence of trains, the birth of cinema and modern ideas and representations of time.

I’ve presented it as a two-sided video; the forward-facing journey on one side and the rear looking journey on the reverse. The screen becomes a meniscus of the present, separating the past and the future.” - Daniel Crooks

results.title: Mother Courage
results.material_description: video, monitor, van, mixed media props, paintings, colour and sound
results.brief_description: Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

results.description:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

“The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.
‘Mother Courage’ is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, ‘Mother Courage and her Children’, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.
Thornton’s ‘Mother Courage’ was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.” [Source: ACMI Education resource kit]
description_for_label:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.
‘Mother Courage’ is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, ‘Mother Courage and her Children’, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.
Thornton’s ‘Mother Courage’ was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. results.title: Dot and Keeto
results.brief_description: Dot tumbles into a secret world when she shrinks to insect size in this enchanting tale. Dot and her new friend Keeto the Mosquito become involved in many adventures whilst searching for the secret bark that will return Dot to her normal size. Dot encounters many strange creatures during her searches, including the lovable Butterwalk the Caterpillar, Atlantis the Praying Mantis and the ruthless Queen Ant.

results.title: Mystery at castle house
results.creator_credit: Peter Maxwell, Brendon Lunney and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: Spider, an adventurous 12 year old, takes his new friends, Ben and Kate, across the harbour to a deserted old mansion, Castle House. Two other boys disappear before their eyes in the overgrown grounds, the eccentric elderly owner suddenly returns, and Spider and his friends find a secret tunnel. Filmed around the natural bushland and bays of Sydney Harbour, it’s action all the way with enough crazy fun to keep children and their parents spellbound.

results.title: Mr Squiggle and Friends
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Julia Kalytis and Pam Verrall
results.brief_description: Mr. Squiggle and his friends have been entertaining Australian children for almost 30 years on ABC television. Now he lives in Bandywallop and is just as much fun as ever. This first video of Mr. Squiggle has all his favourite friends including Roxanne, sharing adventures with Bill and Gus, Merv Wallop and his nephew Wayne. Episodes include : “Squiggle”, “Settlers’ Week”, “The Knapsack”. Rated: G

results.title: One designer, two designer
results.creator_credit: Alexander Stitt, Phillip Adams and Industrial Design Council of Australia
results.brief_description: This animated short film comically explores the importance of good design and the pitfalls of impractical design. It discusses the function of designers and designs, emphasising the need for the consumer to be more critical and thoroughly check each product before purchasing and the value of looking past attractive advertising slogans.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alexander Stitt, Phillip Adams and Industrial Design Council of Australia

results.title: Fat pigs are out
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and Tony Doogood
results.brief_description:
Film follows a farmer as he foolishes fatens his pigs, only to discover on market day that ‘Fat pigs are out!’. He is then taken to an abattoir and shown the difference between fatty pork and the lean pork that the ‘modern housewife’ now demands.

Comical light-hearted tone throughout. Poor acting and dialogue. Good illustrated titles and ‘The End’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and Tony Doogood

results.title: A Crop of records
results.brief_description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.
results.description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.
description_for_label: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

results.title: Marmalade
results.brief_description:
Takes viewer through the process of cutting citrus fruit, cooking it and bottling it as marmalade. A woman prepares the marmalade and a male voice narrates the process.

Good titles/ ‘The End’. Nice colour.
